dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: Long-term Population and Community Dynamics: Fishes, ongoing since 2005

address.deliveryPoint: Center for Ocean Health, Long Marine Lab

abstract.para: These data describe the species abundance and size distributions of fishes surveyed as part of MCR LTER's annual reef fish monitoring program. This study began in 2005 and the dataset is updated annually. The abundances of all mobile taxa of fishes (Scarids, Labrids, Acanthurids, Serranids, etc.) observed on a five by fifty meter transect which extends from the bottom to the surface of the water column are recorded by a diver using SCUBA. The diver then swims back along a one by fifty meter section of the original transect line and records the abundances of all non-mobile or cryptic taxa of fishes (Pomacentids, Gobiids, Cirrhitids, Holocentrids etc). Surveys are conducted between 0900 and 1600 hours (Moorea time) during late July or early August each year. In 2006, divers also began to estimate the size (length) of each fish observed to the nearest half cm. Four replicate transects are surveyed in each of six locations on the forereef (two on each of Moorea's three sides), six locations on the backreef (two on each of Moorea's three sides) and on six locations on the fringing reef (two on each of Moorea's three sides) for a total of 72 individual transects. Transects are permanently marked using a series of small, stainless steel posts affixed to the reef. Transects on the forereef are located at a depth of approximately 12m, those on the backreef are located at a depth of approximately 1.5m and those on the fringing reef are located at a depth of approximately 10m. In addition to the biotic data collected, divers also record data on the date and time each transect was surveyed, wind speed and sea state, swell height in m, amount of cloud cover in % and horizontal visability in m. This monitoring program is consistent with the protocols adopted by the Global Coral Reef Monitoring Network and the Australian Institute of Marine Science for use with the Great Barrier Reef Long-term Monitoring Program.

This material is based upon work supported by the U.S. National Science Foundation under Grant No. OCE 16-37396 (and earlier awards) as well as a generous gift from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. Research was completed under permits issued by the French Polynesian Government (Délégation à la Recherche) and the Haut-commissariat de la République en Polynésie Francaise (DTRT) (Protocole d'Accueil 2005-2022). This work represents a contribution of the Moorea Coral Reef (MCR) LTER Site.

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para: This data package is released under the Creative Commons license Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0 , see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). This license states that consumers ("Data Users" herein) may distribute, adapt, reuse, remix, and build upon this work, as long as they give appropriate credit, provide a link to the license, and indicate if changes were made. If redistributed, a Data User may not apply additional restrictions or technological measures that prevent access.

The Data User has an ethical obligation to cite the data source appropriately in any publication or product that results from its use, and notify the data contact or creator. Communication, collaboration, or co-authorship (as appropriate) with the creators of this data package is encouraged to prevent duplicate research or publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplication or inappropriate use. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation may occur if data are used outside of the context of the original study. The Data User should be aware that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data.

While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. This data package (with its components) is made available "as is" and with no warranty of accuracy or fitness for use. The creators of this data package and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for any damages resulting from misinterpretation, use or misuse of the data package or its components.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: LTER 1 polygon including LTER 0 on north shore

description.para: This is an ongoing dataset. Data are added every year.

changeHistory.oldValue: previously did not include taxonomic family

changeHistory.comment: Split the dataTable into two separate tables because the initial year data differ in method and measurements. Began appending YYYYMMDD to download file names to distinguish versions. Biomass attribute added.
Trophic Groups columns added to the ongoing survey data table. Methods and References added.
Length anomaly flag column added to the ongoing survey data table.
In 3rd table, switching to NA for missingValueCode since these are string, not numeric fields.
End is a reserved keyword so changed to End_time. Changed Start to Start_time to match. Count is also a reserved keyword so changed to Fish_Count.
Spellings corrected in taxonomy table and a few common names added.
Starting in 2009 the swell, visibility and surge were recorded more precisely than meters so these columns were changed from integer to real numbers.
Appended 2011 survey data. No change to earlier years' data.
For fish identified only to the family level, the family column had previously reported the order. Now the family column reports the family in all cases.

changeHistory.oldValue: Calculated weight of given count, size and species.
changeHistory.comment: Revision 43: Added word total to clarify this is the total weight. Also added sentence to methods to clarify the biomass is that combined for a given count of a size class of a species. These clarifications are in response to data user feedback.

changeHistory.oldValue: Forereef transect is 12m depth, not 15m depth.
changeHistory.comment: Revision 44: Corrected a typo on a transect depth. Also added shark keyword.
Revision 45: Year and date columns of table 1 now datetime storageType so Kepler will recognize.
Revision 49: Appended 2013 survey data. Revised species table per CAS.
Revision 51 only for purpose of going to anonymous data download from network catalog.
Revision 56 adds a new dataTable, separating the extra survey sites from the annual survey sites. Methods clarified. A few rows of 2016 data were corrected for fish length mm to cm conversion.

Revision 57 changes the times in hh:mm back to dateTime data type now that the time without date is added back into the list of preferred dateTime formatStrings. Next revision will have all times in local time not UTC. This is the last revision in UTC. Revision 57 also uses updated trophic data.
Revision 58 adds 2019 survey data. The Extra Fish Survey file is also updated; although it is 2015 survey data, the related trophic and biomass calculations update.

section.title: Diver Observation
section.para: This study began in 2005 and the dataset is updated annually. The abundances of all mobile taxa of fishes (Scarids, Labrids, Acanthurids, Serranids, etc.) observed on on a five by fifty meter transect which extends from the bottom to the surface of the water column are recorded by a diver using SCUBA. The diver then swims back along a one by fifty meter section of the original transect line and records the abundances of all non-mobile or cryptic taxa of fishes (Pomacentids, Gobiids, Cirrhitids, Holocentrids etc). Surveys are conducted between 0900 and 1600 hours (Moorea local time) during late July or early August each year. In 2006, divers also began to estimate the size (length) of each fish observed to the nearest half cm. Four replicate transects are surveyed in each of six locations on the forereef (two on each of Moorea's three sides), six locations on the backreef (two on each of Moorea's three sides) and on six locations on the fringing reef (two on each of Moorea's three sides) for a total of 72 individual transects. Transects are permanently marked using a series of small, stainless steel posts affixed to the reef. Transects on the forereef are located at a depth of approximately 12m, those on the backreef are located at a depth of approximately 1.5m and those on the fringing reef are located at a depth of approximately 10m.

section.title: Locations
section.para: Annual fish census locations are labeled with four components in a stratified design: 6 sites, 3 habitats, 4 transects, 2 swaths. (The swaths are the transect widths of 1 m and 5 m.) Therefore there are 144 unique locations surveyed each year. The six MCR-LTER sites span the three shores of the roughly triangular island of Moorea with Sites 1 and 2 on the north-facing shore, Sites 3 and 4 on the south-east-facing shore, and Sites 5 and 6 on the south-west-facing shore. At each site, the three habitats are the Fringing Reef, Backreef, and Forereef. At each habitat, there are four transects. Each transect has two swaths. The two swaths are described in the Diver Observation method step.
Use of the term transect here will be further clarified in the next revision of this dataset's methods. Correspondence with the author is encouraged in the meantime.

section.title: Dive Conditions
section.para: In addition to the biotic data collected, divers also record data on the date and time each transect was surveyed, wind speed and sea state, swell height in m, amount of cloud cover in % and horizontal visibility in m. Dive conditions are recorded for each dive, which is unique to a habitat at a site for a year. Therefore there are 18 unique dive conditions each year (3 habitats at 6 sites).

section.title: Divers
section.para: At each site, at each habitat, there are four transects, each covered by an assigned diver (in 2005 by 2 divers). Whenever possible, the same diver covers the same transect number every year. (Transect 3 has varied.) The diver is listed by their initials. (In 2005, the initials of 2 divers are concatenated.) The diver ID is determined by the year and transect number; there are 4 unique diver IDs for each year.

section.title: Reference for fish census protocol
section.para: The MCR-LTER annual fish census is based on the 'Fish Belt Transect' method described in: 'Methods for Ecological Monitoring Of Coral Reefs: A Resource For Managers. Version 1.', J. Hill and C. Wilkinson, 2004, Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS), Townsville, Australia. 117 p.

section.title: Estimation of biomass from length
section.para:
Calculated fish biomass is a wet weight. Fish biomass (body weight in g) is estimated using the formula w = aL^b where L is the fish fork length (FL) in cm and parameters a and b depend on species. Parameters were obtained primarily from Kulbicki et al. 2005.
Diver observations of fish length are collected and reported in this dataset as total length. The conversion to fork length was determined primarily using FishBase.

section.title: References for taxonomy
section.para: Definitive source of taxonomic levels from family to species: Eschmeyer, W. N. (ed.) 'Catalog of Fishes' electronic version (6 May 2010). http://research.calacademy.org/ichthyology/catalog/fishcatmain.asp

Citation for taxonomic levels from phylum to family: Nelson, J.S., 'Fishes of the World', 4th Ed. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Hoboken, New Jersey, 601 p., 2006 as well as recent rulings by the ICZN http://iczn.org/
Citation for taxonomic levels below family: Randall, J.E., 'Reef and Shore Fishes of the South Pacific', University of Hawaii Press, Honolulu, Hawaii, 707 p., 2005

section.title: References for trophic groups and biomass from length
section.para: Karplus I, Thompson AR (2010) The partnership between gobiid fishes and burrowing alpheid shrimps. In: Patzner RA, VanTassell JL, Larson HK, Kapoor BG (eds) The biology of gobies. Science Publishers, Inc., New Hampshire
Kulbicki M., N. Guillemot M. Amand, 2005, A general approach to length-weight relationships for New Caledonian lagoon fishes, Cybium, 29: 235-252
Froese, R. and D. Pauly. Editors. 2010. FishBase. World Wide Web electronic publication. www.fishbase.org, version (07/2010).

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biological Sciences, California State University

dataTable.entityDescription: Fish transect visual counts repeated annually include species, fish length, estimated biomass, and trophic group.

section.title: Fish Length and Biomass
section.para: In 2006, divers also began to estimate the size (length) of each fish observed to the nearest half cm.

section.title: Divers
section.para: At each site, at each habitat, there are four transects, each covered by an assigned diver (one diver per transect). Whenever possible, the same diver covers the same transect number every year. (Transect 3 has varied.) The diver is listed by their initials. The diver ID is determined by the year and transect number; there are 4 unique diver IDs for each year.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year of Observation
Day of Observation
Start time of transect observation in UTC, as hh:mm.
End time of transect observation in UTC, as hh:mm.
One of 192 locations. Location name concatenates site, habitat, transect, and swath.
Name of the site.
Name of the habitat.
Transect number.
Width of transect. Defines set of fish surveyed; see methods.
Taxonomic name to lowest level possible, in most cases the species binomial.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: The observation was the absence of fish.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Taxonomic family.
Number of fishes of a given total length counted on a transect.
Fish total length (includes tail fin). Estimated to 5mm in most cases.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: partially hidden so length not measureable

attribute.attributeDefinition: Flag if length is greater than authoritative recorded maximum length by more than 10 percent.

codeDefinition.definition: anomaly; observed length exceeds reference maximum by more than 10 percent
no anomaly; observed length is less than or within 10 percent of reference maximum

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: not compared to reference or no applicable reference

attribute.attributeDefinition: Calculated total weight of given count, size and species.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: not available
format string length exceeded

attribute.attributeDefinition: Fish grouped according to what they eat.

codeDefinition.definition: Feed primarily or largely on fishes
Feed primarily on zooplankton; includes all planktivores from Fine Trophic Group; also includes many omnivores which feed primarily on zooplankton but also on benthic algae
Feed primarily on algae and/or detritus; includes all Herbivore/Detritivores from Fine Trophic Group and some omnivores
Feed primarily on non-planktonic animals including corals and other benthic invertebrates, but not fishes (may feed on fishes to some extent)

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: not applicable

attribute.attributeDefinition: Fish grouped according to what they eat.

codeDefinition.definition: Feed primarily on benthic invertebrates; may also feed on fishes to some extent
Include scleractinian corals as a major part of their diet; Many of these species also feed on other benthic invertebrates and/or algae
Feed primarily on the mucous and scales of fish
Feed exclusively on algae, plant material, and/or detritus
Includes significant amounts of animal material (including benthic invertebrates and/or zooplankton but not coral) and plant/algal material in diet.
Feed primarily or largely on fishes

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: not applicable

attribute.attributeDefinition: Estimated percent cloud cover at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated wind velocity at the start time of the transect observation up to 5 Beaufort.
Estimated sea state at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated swell at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated visibility under water at the start time of the transect observation. 51 means greater than 50.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: value not recorded

attribute.attributeDefinition: Estimated surge at the start time of the transect observation.
Initials of SCUBA diver.

dataTable.entityDescription: Fish transect visual counts the first year replicated some sites and omitted fish length. Protocol and data differ from long-term series.

section.title: Initial Survey
section.para: This study began in 2005 with an initial survey. Protocol and data collected differ from the annual survey in subsequent years. Size (fish length) was not collected in 2005.
In the initial survey in 2005, the Forereef habitat transects at sites LTER 1 and LTER 2 were replicated three times. All other sites and habitats have one replicate.

section.title: Divers
section.para: At each site, at each habitat, there are four transects, each covered by a pair of assigned divers in 2005.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year of Observation
Day of Observation
Start time of transect observation in UTC, as hh:mm.
End time of transect observation in UTC, as hh:mm.
One of 192 locations. Location name concatenates site, habitat, transect, and swath.
Name of the site.
Name of the habitat.
Transect number.
Width of transect. Defines set of fish surveyed; see methods.
Taxonomic name to lowest level possible, in most cases the species binomial.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: The observation was the absence of fish.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Taxonomic family. Exception: (rare) if taxonomy is known at only genus or family level then this column contains a higher taxonomic level.
Number of fishes of a given total length counted on a transect.
Estimated percent cloud cover at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated wind velocity at the start time of the transect observation up to 5 Beaufort.
Estimated sea state at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated swell at the start time of the transect observation.
Estimated visibility under water at the start time of the transect observation. 51 means greater than 50.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: value not recorded

attribute.attributeDefinition: Estimated surge at the start time of the transect observation.
Initials of SCUBA divers.
